summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to various recipients, primarily alleging massive, ongoing securities fraud involving Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial (NITE/VIRT). Dilorio accuses the SEC, Jefferies, and others of criminal obstruction, covering up illegal naked short selling and money laundering through OTC markets, and facilitating fraudulent mergers while protecting key figures. He references his own whistleblower claims and connects the fraud to other cases and individuals. This document is a lengthy email from whistleblower Christopher Dilorio to the SEC, appealing the denial of his award claim for the Oppenheimer AML covered action (2015-016). He alleges the SEC used his information from his 2013 TCR (Tip, Complaint, or Referral) to bring the Oppenheimer/Gibraltar complaints but obstructed a full investigation to protect major market makers like Knight/NITE and UBS (UBSS). He details a complex web of alleged money laundering through penny stock shells, implicating numerous individuals and entities, and accuses the SEC of criminal obstruction and facilitating ongoing fraud.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of securities fraud, naked short selling, money laundering, and SEC corruption related to Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial.

persons.name: Cifu
persons.context: Referenced as the CEO of Virtu Financial (VIRT) who allegedly admits the importance of retail/OTC market trading to NITE/VIRT's revenue model and is involved in balance sheet fraud.

persons.name: Handler
persons.context: Repeatedly accused of having a corrupt, criminal relationship with the SEC to protect Jefferies' interests as a major shareholder in KCG and facilitate fraudulent mergers.

persons.name: Daniel Coleman
persons.context: Quoted in a 2017 SEC filing regarding KCG's first-quarter performance amid low market volatility.

persons.name: Glenn Hutchins
persons.role: Co-founder of Silver Lake, former Blackstone
persons.context: Described as a friend of Jay Clayton, involved in buying and selling SunGard, and a co-founder of North Island, a top shareholder in NITE/VIRT.

persons.name: Greifeld
persons.context: Former CEO of NASDAQ who was a director at Automated Securities Clearance Ltd, which was sold to SunGard; later involved with North Island, a top NITE/VIRT investor.

persons.name: Adena Friedman
persons.context: Current NASDAQ CEO who signed off on NASDAQ's acquisition of the BRUT ECN from SunGard.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: Subject of a joint SEC/SDNY complaint; Dilorio believes exculpatory evidence is being withheld due to a corrupt relationship between the SEC/SDNY and Handler/Jefferies.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Addressed by Dilorio, who applauds her reproof of the SDNY and urges her to look at the Dan Kamensky case.

persons.name: Judge Cave
persons.context: Addressed multiple times by Dilorio regarding the corrupt relationship between the SEC, Handler, Jefferies, and NITE.

persons.name: Judge Jones
persons.context: Addressed by Dilorio with allegations of SEC corruption and fraud on the court related to the VIRT/KCG merger.

persons.name: Blostein
persons.context: Goldman Sachs analyst referenced by Dilorio regarding modeling of NITE/VIRT OTC market share volumes and their correlation to trading profits.

persons.name: Repetto
persons.context: Sell-side analyst referenced in connection with Jefferies and questions about NITE/VIRT.

persons.name: Fannon
persons.context: Sell-side analyst referenced alongside Repetto regarding questions about NITE/VIRT.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Former SEC Chairman accused of not recusing himself from decisions involving NITE/VIRT despite conflicts of interest related to his former firm Sullivan & Cromwell and colleague Jared Fishman.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Attorney at Sullivan Cromwell alleged by Dilorio to have advised Knight/KCG/Virtu on transactions that facilitated ongoing fraud, creating conflicts for SEC Chair Clayton.

persons.name: Janey
persons.role: SEC Official (likely in Office of the Whistleblower)
persons.context: SEC recipient of Dilorio's emails, accused of failing to produce the full record for his whistleblower award denial and being part of the obstruction.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: SEC Inspector General referenced as corrupt and precluded from involvement due to Clayton's conflicts.

persons.name: Norberg
persons.role: SEC Official (likely in Office of the Whistleblower)
persons.context: SEC official accused of creating extraordinary reasons for denying Dilorio's whistleblower award, including claiming SEC investigators never saw his information.

persons.name: Berger
persons.role: SEC Official (likely in Office of the Whistleblower)
persons.context: SEC official with whom Dilorio filed his 2013 TCR (Tip, Complaint, or Referral).

persons.name: Joshie Sason
persons.context: Referenced as a 'bag man' involved in Hanover/Magna and other shell companies, subject of an SEC complaint that Dilorio claims is based on his information.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Referenced as a 'bag man' involved with JMJ and money laundering shells like Blink Charging; barred by FINRA as a 'Bad Actor'.

persons.name: Ajay Tandon
persons.context: Co-founder of SeeThruEquity, LLC, subject of an SEC complaint for pump-and-dump schemes involving Net Element (NETE).

persons.name: Amit Tandon
persons.context: Co-founder of SeeThruEquity, LLC, subject of an SEC complaint for pump-and-dump schemes involving Net Element (NETE).

persons.name: Richard Best
persons.context: SEC NY official who brought a FINRA complaint against Brown Brothers Harriman based on Dilorio's information.

persons.name: Schwarzman
persons.context: Mentioned as someone Glenn Hutchins worked with at Blackstone.

persons.name: Christopher Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the email and submitter of multiple TCRs to the SEC and FINRA, alleging massive fraud, money laundering, and SEC obstruction related to penny stock shells, Knight Capital/NITE, and UBS.

persons.name: Justin W. Keener
persons.context: Charged by the SEC in 2020 for operating as an unregistered dealer; alleged by Dilorio to be involved in money laundering penny stock shells like IMDS and CGFIA, connected to NITE and UBSS trading.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.role: Individual charged in SEC microcap fraud complaint
persons.context: Charged by the SEC in 2019 for roles in microcap frauds; alleged by Dilorio to be connected to Hanover/Magna and involved in money laundering shells like NewLead and CGFIA.

persons.name: Jane Norberg
persons.role: SEC Office of the Whistleblower Chief
persons.context: Recipient of Dilorio's appeal; the SEC OWB chief who issued the preliminary denial of his award claim for the Oppenheimer action.

persons.name: Sean McKessy
persons.context: Former head of the SEC Office of the Whistleblower; Dilorio corresponded with him and Robin Traxler at FINRA in 2012 regarding his claims.

persons.name: Robin Traxler
persons.context: FINRA official with whom Dilorio had extensive correspondence in 2012 about penny stock shells CGFIA and AppTech, which were later cited in FINRA's Oppenheimer AML complaint.

persons.name: Dan Coleman
persons.context: Became CEO of KCG after the merger; previously ran Equities at UBS during its Reg SHO and cross-border AML issues; alleged by Dilorio to be part of the protected network.

persons.name: Andrew Cifu
persons.context: CEO of Virtu, which acquired KCG/NITE; alleged by Dilorio to have refused to publish KCG's 2Q2017 financials and obscured OTCM trading volumes post-merger.

persons.name: Carl Hoecker
persons.context: SEC IG accused by Dilorio of conducting inadequate investigations into his complaints, failing to interview him, and not informing Congress of serious allegations.

persons.name: Steven Peikin
persons.context: SEC Enforcement co-director accused by Dilorio of conflicts and of recusing himself from matters involving NITE/Virtu.

persons.name: Michael Farkas
persons.context: CEO of Blink; mentioned in connection with Skyway Communications, whose registration was revoked by the SEC in 2007, as part of the network of shell companies.

persons.name: Jonathan New
persons.context: CFO of Blink; formerly CFO of AQR/Crede, linked to Milken and alleged money laundering.

persons.name: Donald Engel
persons.context: Director of Blink who worked at Drexel with Michael Milken.

persons.name: David Della Sciucca, Jr.
persons.context: Named in the SEC Gibraltar complaint as a nominee involved with the Magnum d'Or shell.

persons.name: Oleg Firer
persons.context: CEO of Net Element, a NASDAQ-listed company alleged by Dilorio to be a money laundering shell with numerous AML red flags; former head of Acies.

persons.name: Terren Peizer
persons.role: Executive at Crede, involved with Net Element
persons.context: Ran Crede, a Milken-related entity; involved with Net Element (NETE) alongside felon partner Michael Wachs.

persons.name: Martin Schlaff
persons.context: Austrian/Israeli individual controlling Alpha Capital Anstalt, linked to various shells including IMDS and the Frost/Honig/Stetson complaint.

persons.name: Tom Priore
persons.context: CEO of Priority Tech Holdings, an AQR blank check shell, described as a well-known fraudster to the SEC.

persons.name: David Urban
persons.role: Trump PA Campaign Manager, NITE Board Member
persons.context: Sits on the board of NITE/Virtu and is also on the board of his own alleged money laundering shell, FSD Pharma.

persons.name: John McCarthy
persons.role: Former SEC NY official, Knight/KCG Chief Counsel
persons.context: Former SEC NY official who ended up as Chief Counsel for Knight/KCG; cited in the context of the Madoff investigation failures.

persons.name: Vikas Arora
persons.context: IRS Criminal Investigation agent who, with Nathan Sarnacki, met with Dilorio in Denver in April 2016 regarding his TCRs.

persons.name: Nathan Sarnacki
persons.context: IRS Criminal Investigation agent who, with Vikas Arora, met with Dilorio in Denver in April 2016.

persons.name: Marc P. Berger
persons.context: SEC attorney named on the Sason/Magna/NewLead complaint; also the law firm Berger Montague helped Dilorio file his 2013 TCR.

connections.description: Dilorio repeatedly accuses Handler (CEO of Jefferies) of being in a corrupt, criminal relationship with the SEC to facilitate fraud and protect Jefferies' interests in KCG/VIRT.
Dilorio accuses Cifu (CEO of Virtu Financial) of orchestrating accounting fraud, misleading disclosures, and being part of the SEC-facilitated merger fraud.
Alleged to have worked together with the SEC to orchestrate the VIRT/KCG merger using fraudulent balance sheet valuations and write-downs.
Colleagues at Sullivan & Cromwell; Dilorio alleges Fishman played a key role in keeping NITE/VIRT running and Clayton had conflicts of interest.
Co-founders of North Island, which became a top shareholder in NITE/VIRT; connected through SunGard and NASDAQ transactions.
Kamensky's case involves Jefferies (Handler's firm) as the investment bank; Dilorio alleges the SEC/SDNY are withholding exculpatory evidence to protect Handler/Jefferies.
Dilorio sends numerous emails to Janey (SEC official) detailing allegations and appealing the denial of his whistleblower award.
Both are described as 'bag men' involved in money laundering shells and subject to SEC/FINRA actions that Dilorio claims are based on his information.
Dilorio is appealing the SEC OWB's denial of his award claim to Chief Norberg, accusing the SEC of using his information unethically.
Alleged that NITE was the top trader/executing broker for Keener/JMJ's money laundering penny stock shells like IMDS and CGFIA.
Sason is linked to Hanover/Magna entities, which were involved in converting bogus obligations into worthless certificates dumped via shells like NewLead and CGFIA.
Alleged to have traded billions of shares in the same penny stock money laundering shells (CGFIA, IMDS, APCX) and to be protected by SEC obstruction.
Coleman previously ran Equities at UBS during its Reg SHO violations and cross-border AML issues before becoming CEO of KCG.

connections.person2: Multiple Associates (Farkas, Engel, Handler, Feinberg, etc.)
connections.description: Milken is described as the nexus of a network involving Drexel alumni and entities linked to junk bonds, shell companies, and alleged money laundering.
Dilorio corresponded with then-OWB Chief McKessy and Robin Traxler at FINRA in 2012, providing information later used in complaints.
SEC IG Hoecker is accused by Dilorio of failing to properly investigate his complaints, not interviewing him, and obstructing Congress.

events.title: Knight Capital 'Glitch'
events.description: Knight Capital suffered a massive trading loss due to a 'glitch,' which Dilorio alleges was a cover-up for insolvency resulting from illegal naked shorting and marked the beginning of ongoing SEC-facilitated fraud.

events.title: VIRT/KCG Merger Closing
events.description: Virtu Financial (VIRT) acquired KCG Holdings in a $1.4 billion all-cash merger. Dilorio alleges the deal was fraudulent, with the SEC, Handler, and Cifu writing down over $4 billion in naked short fails to inflate the acquisition price.

events.title: Dilorio's Initial TCR Filing
events.description: Christopher J. Dilorio filed his first Tip, Complaint, or Referral (TCR) with the SEC Office of the Whistleblower, alleging illegal naked short selling and fraud at Knight Capital.

events.title: VIRT Q3 2020 Earnings Call
events.description: Virtu Financial held its Q3 2020 earnings call. Dilorio criticizes the lack of tough questions from sell-side analysts regarding balance sheet fraud and undisclosed OTC market trading volumes.

events.title: SEC Preliminary Denial of Dilorio's Award
events.description: The SEC preliminarily denied Christopher J. Dilorio's whistleblower award application for his Opco claims, which he alleges is part of a scheme to run out the clock and protect criminals.

events.title: SEC Complaint Against SeeThruEquity
events.description: The SEC filed a complaint against SeeThruEquity, LLC and the Tandon brothers for pump-and-dump schemes, including involving Net Element (NETE), which Dilorio had alerted the SEC to.

events.title: Knight Capital "Trading Glitch"
events.description: Knight Capital suffered a massive trading loss due to a software glitch, leading to an emergency bailout financed by a consortium of firms. Dilorio alleges this proved Knight was insolvent and that the SEC orchestrated the bailout to protect a criminal enterprise.

events.title: Dilorio/Berger TCR Submission to SEC
events.description: Christopher Dilorio, with law firm Berger Montague, submitted a detailed TCR to the SEC alleging massive fraud, money laundering, and naked shorting by Knight/NITE and UBS in penny stock shells like CGFIA and IMDS.

events.title: SEC Oppenheimer AML Action (Covered Action 2015-016)
events.description: The SEC brought an administrative proceeding against Oppenheimer & Co. for anti-money laundering failures related to penny stock trading. Dilorio claims this action was based on his information but was limited to protect NITE and UBS.

events.title: DTCC Global Lock on CGFIA Stock
events.description: The DTCC imposed a 'Global Lock' on Colorado Goldfields Inc. (CGFIA) stock due to actions by a third-party broker-dealer, which Dilorio cites as clear evidence of naked shorting.

events.title: SEC Charges Against Joshua Sason et al.
events.description: The SEC charged Joshua Sason and others for roles in microcap frauds and unlawful offerings, including related to NewLead. Dilorio claims this was based on his earlier TCRs.

events.title: SEC Charges Against Justin W. Keener/JMJ Financial
events.description: The SEC charged Justin Keener for operating as an unregistered penny stock dealer. Dilorio alleges the SEC knew about Keener for years from his TCRs and that NITE executed his trades.

events.title: Virtu Financial Acquisition of KCG
events.description: Virtu Financial acquired KCG (formerly Knight Capital). Dilorio alleges the transaction was fraudulent, involved writing down billions in naked short fails, and was facilitated by SEC obstruction.

locations: Santa Monica, California (HQ of New Concepts shell)
Denver, Colorado / Littleton, Colorado (CGFIA 'world HQ' and CEO Guyer's home)
Neuchatel, Switzerland (Antelope Technologies, connected to CGFIA's Guyer)
The Woodlands, Texas / Boca Raton, Florida (AppTech offices)
Miami, Florida (Residence of Justin Keener, Oleg Firer)
keyFacts: Christopher J. Dilorio, an SEC whistleblower, alleges a massive, ongoing fraud involving Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial (NITE/VIRT), centered on illegal naked short selling of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering.

Dilorio claims the SEC, under Chairman Jay Clayton, has criminally obstructed investigations to protect Jefferies (CEO Handler), Virtu Financial (CEO Cifu), and other entities, facilitating fraudulent mergers like the 2017 VIRT/KCG deal.

The whistleblower asserts that NITE/VIRT's core business model is abusive naked shorting and money laundering, which is intentionally hidden from investors and regulators, making the firm 'grossly insolvent' repeatedly.

Dilorio connects the fraud to a wider network including individuals like Glenn Hutchins, former NASDAQ CEO Greifeld, and 'bag men' like Joshie Sason and Justin Keener, alleging an ecosystem of shell companies and pump-and-dump schemes.

He references his own denied whistleblower award as evidence of SEC corruption and calls for immediate halts of trading in NITE/VIRT, shutdown of the OTC market and Obligation Warehouse, and resignations at the SEC.

The whistleblower, Christopher Dilorio, alleges the SEC used his 2013 TCR information to bring the Oppenheimer/Gibraltar AML actions but intentionally obstructed a full investigation to protect major market makers Knight/NITE and UBS (UBSS).
Dilorio presents the DTCC's 2013 'Global Lock' on CGFIA stock as 'smoking gun' evidence of naked shorting by executing broker-dealers, which the SEC failed to fully investigate.

The document claims Knight Capital was insolvent by August 2011, and the August 2012 'glitch' was a bailout orchestrated by the SEC to protect a 'criminal enterprise' engaged in abusive naked shorting of penny stock shells for money laundering.

Dilorio accuses the SEC Office of the Whistleblower and Inspector General Carl Hoecker of gross negligence and criminal obstruction for denying his award claim, failing to interview him, and not informing Congress of his serious allegations.

A complex network of individuals and entities is described, linking Michael Milken, his associates, various shell companies (AQR blanks, NewLead, FreeSeas, Net Element), and political figures (Trump, Kushner) to alleged money laundering facilitated by SEC inaction.
